intro: Caopia tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly caopia, is a perennial plant native to South America. It is characterized by its hairy, grayish foliage and branched stems that often grow close to the ground. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in clusters, adding a subtle ornamental value. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and covered in a dense layer of fine, white hairs. Caopia tomentosa is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forests or along stream banks.
